description: Subdivision of the existing plot and erection of 2no. x semi-detached two-storey dwellings with associated parking, landscaping and amenity.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from the date of this decision.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990. (As amended)

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of othernuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to beretained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.The demolition and construction of the development shall be carried out in accordance with the construction method statement so agreed.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset, and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the first floor rear facing bathroom windows, as shown on 'AAL-19-256-P03', shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the Pilkington scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the proposed Sustainable Drainage System shall be implemented in accordance with the strategy set out in 'SUDS Report for 1 Sunray Avenue, C2371-R1-REVA' and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Council's Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the 'Energy Statement dated June 2020' including the installation of an Air Source Heat Pump and solar panels prior to the beneficial occupation of the approved dwellings. The implemented measures shall be maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 35% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authorityReason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays.Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of development and notwithstanding the approved drawings, details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority, indicating the positions, design, materials and type of boundary  treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected.  More specifically, the submitted details shall show a chamfered corner, at an angle of 45 degrees, on the NE boundary of Plot 1 which borders the access lane and in closest proximity to the garage associated with No. 3 Sunray Avenue. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details prior to the occupation of the dwellings.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to improve access and egress to the garage associated with No. 3 Sunray Avenue and in the interests of visual amenity and biodiversity, in accordance with Policies DM6 and DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted 2012.

The car parking spaces shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained prior to the occupation of the proposed development and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure adequate on-site parking provision in the interests of highway safety, convenience and amenity, in accordance with CS 7 (Managing Vehicle Use) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the approved drawings and prior to any works above damp proof course level of the development hereby permitted, the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall be implemented prior to the occupation of the development and retained as such for the life of the development.(a) cycle store facilities (materials, design and dimensions)(b) waste and recycling stores (materials, design and dimensions)Reason: To provide adequate cycle store facilities in accordance with Policy 6.9 of the London Plan and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the approved drawings and prior to any works above damp proof course level of the development hereby permitted, a soft and hard landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at the first floor level or above in the side or rear elevations of the dwellings unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to the dwellinghouses hereby permitted, or outbuildings on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for the occupiers of the proposed dwellings and neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no boundary wall or fence shall be erected on the NE boundary of Plot 1 which borders the access lane and in closest proximity to the garage associated with No. 3 Sunray Avenue without incorporating a chamfered corner of 45 degrees.Reason:   In order to maintain safe and practicable access and egress to the garage associated with No. 3 Sunray Avenue, in accordance with Policies DM6 and DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted 2012.

Prior to the commencement of development details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority, demonstrating that both dwellings would be built to fully comply with Building Regulation requirement M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings'. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details and thereafter permanently retained.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure that the development provides a range of homes to meet different needs in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012, and Policies 3.5 and 3.8 Policy 3.8 of the London Plan 2016.

The site comprises an end-terrace dwelling. 17 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received by a neighbouring property relating to: - Effects on trees - Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosur - Inappropriate design/layout - Loss of light/Sunlight - Privacy - Unacceptable or incompatible useThis concern will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.ProposalErection of rear dormer roof extensions and installation of 2no. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversionRelevant Planning History- 23/00373/HOU - Erection of first floor rear extension. Approve on 16.06.2023The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The applicant proposes to construct an L-shaped dormer on the recently approved planning permission 23/00373/HOU, which is for a first floor rear extension. The proposed dormer would not maintain 500mm from the roof ridge, the sides or the eaves of the host dwelling, falling out the guidelines of Policy Guidance 39, of the residential design SPD. Additionally, the approved planning permission 23/00373/HOU in combination with the proposed dormer would appear bulky and highly incongruous in the immediate vicinity of Bonner Hill Road and would be visible from Hampden Road. Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing and design. It is considered that there would be adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Although officers are satisfied that the proposal would not result in an unacceptable loss of sunlight or daylight, given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring property No. 28 and No. 32 Albert Road by reason of overbearing appearance.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling located in a Zone 2 Flood Risk Area.Consultations- 9 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.- RBK Tree and Landscape Officer - No ObjectionThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Tree & Landscape.- Flood Risk- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The applicant submitted plans and elevations that show a proposed rear extension that would extend past the existing extension by 1m. The extension would be located towards the northern flank of the dwelling house, at a distance of 4.5m from neighbouring property No.43 Auckland Road. In total, the proposed rear extension would be 2.8m in depth. The proposed height of the pitched roof (on the side) would be approximately 3.6m and a flat roof height at the rear would be approximately 2.4m.Officers acknowledge that the proposed side/rear extension would be visible from Buckingham Road and the total depth of the proposed rear extension (including the rear extension granted under planning permission 04/12177/FUL) would be approx 4.7m, falling outside the Residential Design SPD. However, the proposed pitched roof would create better uniformity with the pitched roof of the host dwelling, the proposed height would be modest and matching material would reduce harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the wider area.Therefore, the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given that the proposal would be at a substantial distance (4.5m) from No.43 and only extend past the existing rear extension by 1m, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Trees and LandscapePolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by TPOs are not adversely affected.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Tree Protection Plan and an Arboricultural Method Statement, the council's Tree and Landscape officer has assessed the details and has raised no objection to the proposed extension. The submitted Tree Protection Plan and Arboricultural Method Statement will further be secure through conditions. Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Flood Risk Assessment, therefore, a planning condition is required to ensure that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and that appropriate floodproofing of the proposed development has been incorporated, in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling situated on the south-west side of The Roystons.ProposalDemolition of existing garage and erection of single storey rear extension with changes to side fenestrations.Consultations5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History - 23/00976/PAEXT - Erection of single storey rear extension (6.00m in depth, maximum height of 2.80m and eaves height of 2.80m). Prior approval refused on 25.05.2023 for the following reason:As development appears to have begun before the provisions of condition (10) of part A.4 have been satisfied, the works would not benefit from permitted development afforded by Class A, Part 1, Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).- 23/00027/HOU - Erection of single storey rear extension, roof extension with rear dormer and juliet balcony, installation of 2nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Demolition of existing detached garage and shed and erection of single storey rear outbuilding annexe (summer house) with associated hard landscaping parking to the front of the property. Refused on 02.03.2023 for the following reason:The excessive scale and bulk of the proposed single storey rear extension and hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions, along with insufficient details of the proposed hardstanding and associated boundary treatment to the front of the property, would fail to respect, maintain or enhance the character and appearance of the existing dwelling and wider area, contrary to Policies DM10 and DM11 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012), Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, the NPPF 2021 and the Kingston Residential Design SPD (2013).AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed single-storey rear extension would have a staggered finish with a total depth of 6m from the rear wall and a part-parapet, part-pitched roof height totalling 3.2m. Although the depth would fall outside the guidance of the Residential Design SPD for semi-detached dwellings, it would not be visible from the streetscene, it would have a relatively modest height and the proposed material would be similar to the existing dwelling.Therefore, the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. The extension would not significantly affect the nearest ground floor habitable room of No. 15 The Roystons, as they benefit from an existing single storey rear extension that would be at the same depth as the staggered rear extension. No.19 The Roystons sits at a reasonable distance from the boundary or No.17 The Roystons, therefore, significant harm would not be caused by the proposed rear extension.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved, subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 5 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 22/01628/HOU, which states:Condition 5 (Fire Safety Strategy) - Prior to any above ground works (excluding demolition) a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.

Condition 12 (Car Parking Management Plan) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL requires details of a car parking management plan. A site plan has been submitted in addition to a cover letter which provides some information of access arrangements and hard surfacing details. The submitted plan includes no details of signage that will assist users of these parking spaces in understanding the one way access arrangements for the site, as specifically set out in the condition and referenced in the planning committee report for 19/01259/FUL.Similarly, no details have been provided setting out how the spaces will be managed (i.e. whether allocated or not) and how this would be controlled, as required by the condition. As such, this condition cannot be discharged.

In order to discharge condition 12 (Car Parking Management Plan) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL, a more detailed car parking management plan. shall be submitted incouding details of signage that will assist users of the parking spaces in understanding the one way access arrangements for the site and how the spaces will be managed and controlled, as required by the condition.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of single storey rear and side extension.Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey side extension would be set back from the front elevation by approximately 0.5m and it would not affect the existing cat-slide roof feature. It is noted that it would not be set in from the common boundary, however due to its modest width and height and the proposed roof form (pitched roof to the front and parapet roof along the extension) it is considered to be a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area, in general compliance with Policy Guidance 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.Officers note that the existing street scene contains similar examples of the side extensions that abut common boundaries, as such it is considered that the proposed side extension would not have significant impact on the existing street scene. The proposed single storey rear extension, given its modest depth of approximately 3.2m and height of approximately 3.2m and the proposed design, is considered to be a proportionate addition to the host dwelling, in accordance with Policy Guidance 33. The proposed replacement of the existing timber windows to powder coated aluminium windows of similar appearance as per submitted drawings is considered to be acceptable. It is noted that the proposed cladding of the external walls in coloured render (as stated in thes submitted Design & Access Statement) would be approximately 75mm thick. However, insufficient details of the proposed external insulation have been submitted to consider how it would relate to existing architectural detailing on the property (such as mock-Tudor beams) which are characteristic among properties in the area. It is also unclear where the proposed external insulation would be installed and how this would relate to the adjoining semi-detached property.As such insufficient information has been submitted to conclude that the proposed external insulation cladding would not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling,  the adjoining semi-detached property and the existing street scene. The required details It is not considered that details of the external insulation could be secured by way of planning condition as the required information could require changes to the design of the scheme as submitted and it is important to establish whether external insulation would be acceptable in character and design terms.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The proposal would pass the 45 degree test in relation to the nearest habitable openings at the ground floor level at the adjoining properties and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to these properties.As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Planning Fire Strategy Statement, which is considered to be acceptable. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Planning Fire Strategy Statement and thereafter maintainedConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling located within the Flood Zone 2. Proposal Erection of single storey rear extension, first floor side extension and internal alterations to ground floorConsultations9 properties were notified of the proposal.   3 representations have been received in total (for initial and revised consultations) objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/sunlight- Loss of privacy- Increased flood risk as a result of the proposalOfficer response: the above comments will be addressed within the report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Flood Risk; and,- Fire SafetyRelevant Planning History15/16799/HOU Erection of single storey rear and first floor side extensions granted on 12.11.2015Character and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The current scheme is a resubmission of the planning application 15/16799/HOU granted on 12.11.2015. The revised drawings were received to accommodate changes to the proposed single storey rear extension to include a separation distance of approximately 0.5m to the common boundary with the adjoining semi-detached property No 2 Alexandra Drive, which is the only difference when compared to the application 15/16799/HOU.The proposed first floor side extension would be set back from approximately 0.5m from the front of the house. Given its modest width, the proposed scale, mass and bulk as well as the proposed roof form, it is considered to appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area, in accordance with Policy Guidance 36 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. It is noted that separation distance of approximately 1 m to the common boundary would be retained. The proposed single storey rear extension due to its scale and the proposed design would be in-keeping with the host dwelling, in accordance with  Policy Guidance 33. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note the objections raised in written representations regarding the loss of privacy and daylight and concerns about overbearing appearance in relation to the adjoining properties. It is noted that the adjoining property No 2 Alexandra Drive benefits from the single storey rear extension.The proposal would pass the 45 degree and 25 degree test in relation to the adjoining properties and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight. The proposed window to the side elevation at the first floor level would be obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m when measured from the floor level, details of which would be secured via condition. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, separation distances and scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The Flood Risk Form and Flood Risk Assessment submitted by the applicant indicates that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises an end-terrace dwelling.ProposalDemolition of existing conservatory and erection of single storey rear extension.Consultations5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History 23/00020/HOU - Demolition of existing conservatory and erection of part single part two storey rear extension. Prior approval was refused on 06.03.2023 for the following reasons:1. By reason of bulk, depth and design, the proposed development would not appear proportionate or subordinate to the existing dwellinghouse and would appear incongruous from the wider area, thereby conflicting with Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the Council's Residential Design Guidance 2012.2. By reason of height, depth and siting the proposed development would unduly impact the amenities of No. 32 and No. 36 Albert Road by reason of overbearing appearance, as such the proposed development is contrary to Paragraph 130 of the NPPF 2021, Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The applicant previously submitted an application (23/00020/HOU) which was refused as the two storey rear extension would appear bulky in the immediate vicinity of Albert Road. The two-storey rear has now been omitted and the current proposal only involves the demolition of an existing rear extension and the erection of a new single storey rear extension.Officers acknowledge that the proposed single-storey rear extension would have a depth of approximately 3.9 falling outside the guidelines of Policy Guidance 33, of the Residential Design SPD. However, the depth of the extension would not be different from the existing extension on site. Additionally, the slightly sloped pitched roof would be approximately 3.1m in compliance with Policy Guidance 33 and the extension would not be visible from the streetscene. Therefore, the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. The extension would not significantly affect the nearest ground floor habitable room of No. 32 Albert Road, as they benefit from an existing single storey rear extension that would be at the same depth as the proposed rear extension. No.36 Albert Road sits at a reasonable distance from the boundary of No.34 Albert Road, therefore, significant harm would not be caused by the proposed rear extension. Additionally, as mentioned above the existing situation would not be greatly different from the proposed rear extension.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks the following amendments to planning permission reference 21/03821/KPSID:-	Change to landscape levels, a pumped SW solution, foul water pumping to the Victorian block and other associated works.Through the parent permission, a Drainage Strategy was submitted which identified ground levels for the site. In the car park area, ground levels were anticipated as being 15.9m AOD. The new drainage plans submitted now show a change to ground levels in the car park area with levels ranging between 15.45m and 15.9m AOD. The changes to ground levels are considered to be modest in scale and nature. The ground levels themselves were not identified on any of the approved drawings for 21/03821/KPSID and the applicant has confirmed that the changes do not affect the ground level to existing / new buildings and the approved drawings remain accurate. Through the consideration of planning application 21/03821/KPSID, a drainage strategy was found acceptable and secured through conditions 1 and 19. A change to the drainage strategy is now proposed. These are a result of a 3m UKPN 'cable rights only' zone which bisects the site and now requires attenuation storage below the MUGA to the west of the site and, due to the required level of the attenuation tank, a pumped outfall to Thames Water Assets on Burlington Road is now required.  Foul water pumping is also now proposed for the Victorian Block, where the UKPN cable rights zone conflicts with the approved proposals.This NMA application seeks to amend conditions 1 and 19 to reflect the updated drainage strategy. The amended drainage strategy has been considered and found acceptable by the Council's Drainage Officer through a separate discharge of conditions application (23/01715/CLC). The change to the drainage strategy does not impact on the development itself and this change is not considered to give rise to any material issues in terms of character and appearance of the development from the streetscene or to neighbouring amenities. The interests of any third party or body who participated in or were informed of the original decision are not considered to be disadvantaged in any way.Accordingly, the proposed amendments are considered to be non-material and it is recommended that the application be granted.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 19 (Drainage) of planning permission 21/03821/KPSID, which states (as amended through 23/01718/NMA):Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the drainage system as identified in the drawings and documents below shall be implemented in full and permanently maintained thereafter.o	Drainage Management Plan (Shockledge, June 2023)o	Flood Risk Assessment & Surface Water Drainage Strategy (Shockledge June 2023) o	SUDS proforma o	Proposed Below Ground Drainage Layout Plan Drawing 010100 PO8 o	Surface Water and Foul Water Manhole Scheduleo	Below Ground Drainage Construction Details Sheet 1o	Below Ground Drainage Construction Details Sheet 2o	Below Ground Drainage Construction Details Sheet 3o	Below Ground Drainage Construction Details Sheet 4o	Below Ground Drainage Construction Details Sheet 5o	Foul Water Comparison Drawingo	Surface Water Comparison DrawingReason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy SI13 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Application SiteThe site comprises an end of terrace dwelling.The site is not subject to any particular policy designations or environmental constraints.ProposalThe proposal relate to the demolition of existing outbuilding, erection of two storey side, single storey rear extension. Associated changes to fenestration.This application follows granted permission 22/00038/HOU dated 09.03.2022 for the erection of double-storey side extension with first floor and ground floor part rear extensions and associated changes to fenestration. 2 subsequent applications have been submitted following this application. 22/03198/HOU dated 09.12.2022 for the demolition of existing outbuilding, erection of two storey side, single storey rear extension and associated changes to fenestration which was refused for the following reasons;1) The proposed extension by virtue of its size, siting and design would be out of keeping with the character and appearance of the existing dwelling and would appear visually intrusive and overly dominant within the street scene resulting in unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the dwelling and the area, contrary to Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, the NPPF (2021) and policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 20122) It has not been demonstrated through the submission of a Fire Statement that the proposed development would achieve the highest standards of fire safety, contrary to Policy D12(A) of the London Plan (2021).22/03974/HOU dated 01.03.2023 for the demolition of existing outbuilding and erection of part two storey/part single storey side/rear extension which was refused for the following reasons;1)The proposed extension by virtue of its size, siting and design would be out of keeping with the character and appearance of the existing dwelling and would appear visually intrusive and overly dominant within the street scene resulting in unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the dwelling and the area, contrary to Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021, the NPPF (2021) and policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 20122) It has not been demonstrated through the submission of a Fire Statement that the proposed development would achieve the highest standards of fire safety, contrary to Policy D12(A) of the London Plan (2021).This application would need to address these reasons for refusal.Consultation10 Neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and one objection has been received stating;- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- PrivacyAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - Cycle Parking; and- Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The removal of the proposed first floor side extension has dramatically reduced the significant scale of the previously refused applications. The proposed development is now considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and due to the siting of the proposed extensions it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. This reason for refusal has therefore been addressed.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Due to the siting of the proposed development, officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Officers note there would no openings to the side elevation protecting the privacy of the neighbours on Warren Drive South.Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3.Officer Comment:  Officers note the proposed development would result in the loss of the side access to the rear garden and the cycle storage opportunities therein. Officers note that secure cycle parking provision has been detailed within the submitted plans to demonstrate compliance with the above London Plan Policy. Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments:  Compliance with the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021) have been demonstrated  within the Design and access statement. Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. This reason for refusal has therefore been addressed. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
